title: (MIS)FITTING: A SURVEY OF SCALING LAWS
author: Margaret Li (University of Washington), Sneha Kudugunta (University of Washington), Luke Zettlemoyer (University of Washington), ...
relevance_why: This paper discusses scaling laws in neural models, which can inform the optimization of model architectures and hyperparameters relevant to audio and speech processing tasks.
background: The paper surveys scaling laws that govern the performance of machine learning models as their parameters and datasets grow, aiming to guide decisions in architecture and training setup.
contribution: This survey introduces a systematic analysis of existing scaling law literature, revealing underreported details that impact reproducibility and results, promoting better practices in future research.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Prior scaling law studies often lack clarity on experimental setups or fitting methods, which can lead to contradictory findings.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work provides a checklist to ensure critical details are reported, improving the transparency and replicability of future studies.

key_innovation: The proposed checklist helps authors systematically document their methodologies when exploring scaling laws, fostering reproducible research practices.
real_world_impact: Encouraging best practices in reporting can significantly enhance collaboration within the research community and lead to more efficient development of scalable machine learning models.
limitations: The paper does not provide empirical results or case studies that directly demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed checklist.

new_terms.scaling laws: **Scaling laws** are mathematical relationships that express how the performance of machine learning models changes as a function of model size or the amount of training data.
new_terms.replicability: **Replicability** refers to the ability to achieve the same results as another study by following the same methodology.
